intro: Commiphora lasiodisca, commonly known as the African myrrh or wild myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to the arid regions of eastern and southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing plants. The plant is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and small, inconspicuous white flowers. Its bark and resinous exudates have been traditionally used for their aromatic and medicinal properties. The plant's ability to thrive in dry conditions makes it an important component of its native ecosystems.
